user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining code fragments do not need investigation for unreachable-code under Rule 2.1: the function header and the local declaration (void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void) and int status;) are declarations and entry points and cannot be unreachable. The assignment status = pthread_mutex_unlock(...) is an actual call whose result determines control flow and is therefore reachable. The else branch that calls pthread_setcancelstate(...) is reachable for at least one outcome of the call above (i.e. when the function returns the value that causes the else path) and thus is not obviously unreachable. The closing braces and other syntactic parts are not executable statements and therefore not subject to the unreachable-code rule.
